awd_titl_txt: The Ham Radio Science Citizen Investigation (HamSCI) 2022 Workshop; Scranton, Pennsylvania; March 18-19, 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
The ionosphere is an atmospheric region extends from about 50 to 600 miles above the earth’s surface.   This layer of atmosphere has a high concentration of charged particles (ions and electrons) that interact strongly with radio waves.  Complex structures and variations of charged particle densities in the ionosphere alter the behavior of radio wave propagation, greatly affect the radio communications and global navigation satellite systems.  Understanding ionospheric structures and processes will lead to an increased understanding and prediction of these effects.

The Ham Radio Science Citizen Investigation (HamSCI) is a collective of professional researchers and licensed amateur radio operators (a.k.a. hams) with the objective to foster collaborations between the amateur and professional communities for the purposes of advancing scientific research and understanding, encouraging the development of new technologies to support this research, and to provide educational opportunities for the amateur radio community and the general public. To maximize the potential of the ham radio-professional researcher relationship, meetings are needed to bring these groups together to learn about each other’s communities, vocabularies, share ideas, and participate in activities that advance both the scientific field and the radio hobby.

This project will support a 2-day HamSCI workshop to address this need. The 2022 HamSCI Workshop will be the fifth annual U.S. HamSCI Workshop since the inaugural meeting at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in 2018. This workshop series has led to cutting-edge work in the fields of space physics, citizen science, and the use of crowd-sourced ionospheric data. The 2022 HamSCI Workshop theme will be “The Weather Connection,” and will feature prominent leaders in space weather, atmospheric weather, and the connection between them.

Additionally, the 2022 workshop will continue to make headway on topics of past HamSCI meetings, including the use of amateur radio techniques for observing and understanding the physics behind traveling ionospheric disturbances, Sporadic E, the ionospheric response to solar flares and geomagnetic storms, and space weather effects on radio wave propagation. This meeting will also serve as a bi-annual development meeting of the HamSCI Personal Space Weather Station (PSWS), a project funded through the NSF Aeronomy Distributed Array of Small Instruments (DASI) program. Development of the PSWS will lead to a vast improvement of the scientific quality of citizen science observations currently made by the amateur radio community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this award was to host a 2-day Ham Radio Science Citizen Investigation (HamSCI) workshop in March 2022 that brings together members of the professional scientific and amateur radio communities for the purpose of sharing ideas and participating in activities that advance both scientific knowledge and the amateur radio hobby. Additionally, the HamSCI workshop also served as a team meeting for the NSF Distributed Array of Small Instruments HamSCI Personal Space Weather Station (PSWS) project. The 2022 HamSCI workshop was held in a hybrid in-person and online format from March 18-19, 2022. The in-person workshop was held at the U.S. Space and Rocket Center in Huntsville, AL with the virtual portion held on Zoom. The workshop was also simulcast on the Ham Radio 2.0 YouTube channel.

The agenda consisted of 48 presentations from members of both the science and academic communities. Many presenters were members of both. Participation consisted of 210 attendees, including 55 in-person and 155 online. The demographics included people in many stages of their careers, including undergraduate and graduate students, research faculty and staff, tenure-track faculty, industry professionals, and retirees. The theme of the 2022 Workshop was “The Weather Connection”, and featured invited talks by Dr. Tamitha Skov WX6SWW (“The Ionospheric Impacts of Space Weather and our Heightened Awareness of its Effects on Society”) and Mr. Jim Bacon G3YLA (“Evaluation of links between Terrestrial Weather and Sporadic-E”). A keynote address was given by science historian Dr. Chen-Pang Yeang (“Ham Radio and the Discovery of the Ionosphere”). Workshop agenda and recordings of presentations are available at https://hamsci.org/hamsci2022.

The presentations and discussions at this workshop addressed the following intellectual merit objectives: (1) Enabling amateur radio operators and professional scientists to come together to share ideas, techniques, and results pertaining to space weather and space science research questions. (2) Developing an enhanced understanding of ionospheric variability resulting from forcing due to both space and terrestrial weather. (3) Using amateur radio techniques for the characterization and study of ionospheric and propagation phenomena such as traveling ionospheric disturbances, Sporadic E, solar flares, geomagnetic storms, auroral substorms, and tropospheric ducting. (4) Facilitating the development of instrumentation for a new network of HamSCI Personal Space Weather Stations.

The presentations and discussions at this workshop addressed the following broader impact objectives: (1) Strengthening of synergy between professional scientific and amateur radio communities. (2) Development of open technologies and observation networks that can be used in conjunction with existing space science and space weather infrastructure. (3) Development of materials, projects, and products that can be used by groups such as schools, museums, and other educational institutions to teach space and radio science.
